turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Corfiot Italians.
turn.2: In Corfu, two villages on the island bear names testifying to Maltese presence: Maltezika is named after Malta and Cozzella got its name from Gozo.
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: In Cozzella the Franciscan Sisters of Malta opened a convent and a school in 1907. Those two institutions still flourish.
turn.6: In 1923, there were some 1,200 ethnic Maltese in Corfu, but many of them spoke either Greek or the local Corfiot dialect, which still bore traces of the Venetian occupation of the island.
turn.7: What other influences did they have?
turn.8: Because of this Venetian connection, Fascist propagandists tried to build up an irredentist case for Corfu.
turn.9: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.10: Guido Puccio wrote in "Tribuna", a leading Roman newspaper on 12 September 1923, that the Maltese element in Corfu could be used as an instrument to further Italian claims on that island.
turn.12: In 1930, the Maltese in Corfu had their own priest who looked after their welfare while he kept useful contacts with the ecclesiastical and civil authorities in Malta.
